body:
DoD draft: 

Performing something similar to that in the ASE embedding tutorial  "clustering in the embedding space".

For comparing ASE and SVD efficacy:
make an adj matrix using SBM
then using the same num components test SVD and ASE fit
Follow same error analysis at varying number of components on the same adj matrix  and then also with varying insularity
This could be accomplished by recreating the graspologic tutorial using the sk-network SVD mainly because we trust ASE tutorial. 

For runtime, use adj matrix you decide to use for efficacy, just choose a set of vertex sizes and plot node vs time with a line for each us and them

For comparing LSE and Spectral efficacy:
I will follow the same procedure for doing the graspologic tutorial adopted for LSE, which does not involve much change in the original change. 
I will then recreate the sk-network Spectral in the same format of the graspologic  doing the same error analysis as described in the remake of the LSE which follows ASE tutorial. 

The runtime analysis for LSE and Specrtal will follow the same format above.

main thing is just runtime. 

then, may want to look at svd approximation error. doubt the clustering stuff will be necessary unless we see big differences. 

also just want to make sure we understand which of their tools match which of ours

issue.title: compare ZG(2) to minka
issue.body:
to select the number of components in PCA, sklearn uses this: 
https://papers.nips.cc/paper/1853-automatic-choice-of-dimensionality-for-pca.pdf

but graspy uses this: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0167947305002343

compare the two via simulations and see which is better, and if either of us should switch

body: I'd be interested in this issue

issue.title: Make SVD code faster

labels.name: summer_students?
labels.description: Task that may be of interest for a short project

labels.name: ndd
labels.description: tasks that may be appropriate for Neuro Data Design course

issue.body:
I've found that [scipy's implementation of the lanczos algorithm](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.sparse.linalg.eigsh.html) is extremely fast for finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a big, sparse real symmetric square matrix (I'm pretty sure more so than sklearn's `randomized_svd` or scipy's `sparse.linalg.svds`, although this all needs to be tested empirically).

in the case of undirected graphs, our adjacency matrices are going to be square and symmetric, so the singular values will be the eigenvalues (right?), and most of them are going to be pretty sparse

So a potential NDD project could be testing the various algorithms for finding eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and more generally doing SVDs for speed, on different types of matrices, and then using the ones that are fastest in e.g. [SelectSVD](https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/blob/dev/graspologic/embed/svd.py#L173), and then adding some blurb in the docs about when it is appropriate to use which algorithm.

body:
Sim setting:

Sim 1: SVD vs ASE
1. n_verts = [10, 100, 1000, 10000, 100000]
2. Generate an nx1 2D array of latent positions of uniform distribution between 0.1 and 1
3. Generate an RDPG from the 2D array
4. Perform ASE and SVD on the RDPG (with n_components=1) and save the runtimes for each using the timeit.default_timer() method
5. Take the frobenius norm of the latent positions from ASE/SVD and the true latent positions
6. Repeat steps 2-5 for 15 trials per n
7. Plot stripplots for times vs n_verts for ASE and SVD
8. Plot stripplots for frobenius norms vs n_verts for ASE and SVD

Sim 2: Spectral vs LSE
Exact same process as sim 1 except use spectral instead of SVD and LSE instead of ASE

for this i wouldnt worry about multiple runs of each embedding on the same graph. yes, there will be some variance in how long it takes to run even on the same data, but i dont think it'll be huge, and i would rather use that compute time on running 30x more graphs for example. 

how are you timing everything (what commands from what libraries)? 

also, note that runtime will vary depending on input datatype. for now, please use graphs that start as sparse arrays (scipy csr_matrix)

@bdpedigo I'm having trouble with my simulation: particularly in step 5 in the sim setting above. Since the size of the 2D arrays of the true latent positions and the latent positions from ASE/SVD are different, I'm getting an error when I try to do the frobenius norm on them. What should I do about this?
why are they different? should set the mto be the same by making the ASE embed into the true number of components

https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kareef928/graspologic-personal/blob/main/notebooks/norm-test.ipynb

This is a quick notebook of what I'm trying to do; in the last block I'm trying to make ASE embed into the true number of components but I get an error doing so, I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong

@kareef928 thanks for posting the notebook. I think what would help us both the most is if you could write out the math of what model you are trying to sample from, and then we can evaluate if your code is doing that. 

(hint: how many nodes are in the graph you are trying to sample, and how many latent dimensions are in the model?)

@bdpedigo went through the rdpg tutorial and now I understand that the dimension of each vector (d) has to be lower than the number of vectors (n). For example, if I was sampling from np.random.uniform(low=0.1, high=1, size=(5, 2)), then I would set n_components=2 in ASE when I do ASE on the rdpg. I made a change to step 2 in my plan so now I sample from uniform distributions of size nx4, could you confirm that this is what we want?

Exactly! In theory, the dimension needs to be <= the number of nodes. In practice, depending on the algorithm for doing the SVD that you use, it may need to be <= number of nodes - 1. In general, it will likely be << the number of nodes, otherwise using ASE in general is probably a bad idea. 

So, yes, next steps sound good. Though I believe Jovo said set d=1 and just embed into d=1, which also seems fine. I don't feel too strongly.

https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kareef928/graspologic-personal/blob/main/notebooks/spectral-svd-csr.ipynb

@bdpedigo This is a notebook showing the errors I run into when I try to use csr_matrix in the simulation. Should I make note of these errors in the simulation notebook, or is there a way I can use csr_matrix without running into these errors?
